Award.AwardTitle: REU Site in Sustainable Urban Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three year REU Site program in "Sustainable Urban Environments" (SUE) at the University of Cincinnati (UC) will focus on techniques to study Access to Clean Water, Renewable Energy Sources, Carbon-Sequestration Methods, and Improved Urban Infrastructure. The research projects selected for the REU Site are motivated by four of the Grand Challenges for Engineering produced by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE). The goal of this eight-week summer REU Site program is to provide undergraduate students with research training and seminars and workshops on the use of modern technology in conducting and disseminating cross-disciplinary research. The program intends to encourage talented undergraduates to enroll in graduate school by exposing them to research. Students will be placed in teams and guided on a research project by faculty member(s) and a doctoral student. They will participate in a seminar series to train them to conduct research and participate in interactive workshops to provide the research skills to disseminate their findings. Each team will make biweekly presentations and progress reports, and at the end of the program present a technical paper, poster and power-point presentation. The participants will be encouraged to engage in co-authored presentations and publications that make significant contributions to their field of research in the new emerging areas of SUE. Students will also participate in coordinated social and scholastic activities including: 1) a university-wide welcome picnic; 2) a week-long annual Undergraduate Research Poster Forum (URPF), which includes poster presentations, an awards banquet, a distinguished guest lecture, ?People?s Choice Awards, ? and GRE preparation session; and 3) e-journal of papers to disseminate research with UC undergraduate students as co-authors. Finally, pre- and post-surveys by participants and evaluations by judges will be used to conduct the formative and summative assessments.

The REU Site program will introduce undergraduates from diverse engineering backgrounds to engineering and science. This hands-on interdisciplinary laboratory/computer simulation research experience is expected to help in recruiting and retaining students in engineering or science programs. The research projects selected also show how engineers solve problems for society at large, which will be appealing to women and minorities who tend to choose pathways leading to careers that improve quality of life generally. The program will encourage talented undergraduates to enroll in graduate school by exposing them to research. Since 50% of the participants recruited will be minorities and women, the project will increase the number of underrepresented graduate students involved in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established a 3-year (2011-13) REU Site, with a 1-year (2014) no-cost extension, in "Sustainable Urban Environments (SUE)" with a special focus on four Grand Challenges for Engineering produced by the National Academy of Engineering to study “Access to Clean Water, Renewable Energy Sources, Carbon-Sequestration Methods, and Improved Urban Infrastructure” in the Department of Biomedical, Chemical and Environmental Engineering in the College of Engineering and Applied Science at University of Cincinnati. The goal is to provide an 8-week summer full-time in-residence research training and seminars and workshops on the use of modern technology in conducting and disseminating cross-disciplinary research in SUE. The objective is to encourage talented undergraduates to enroll in graduate school by exposing them to research.

Forty-two undergraduate students (20 men + 22 women) from 12 Ph.D. granting and 6 undergraduate (a few offering M.S. degrees) institutions participated. The men consisted of 13 white Caucasians and 7 minorities; and the women consisted of 13 white Caucasians and 9 minorities. Thus, a total of 29 (69%) underrepresented students (women + minorities) participated. Ten of the 42 students who participated have graduated with a B.S. engineering degree and 7 (70%) are pursuing graduate studies; and 32 students are still in school pursuing undergraduate degrees. The SUE REU Site constituents to date have produced 29 publications, which include: 14 papers/presentations by REU participants as sole authors, 2 of which have won paper awards; 6 papers (3 journal and 3 conference papers) by REU participants as co-authors with their mentors; and 9 other papers (2 journal and 7 conference papers) by faculty and graduate students in which NSF REU funding is acknowledged.

In the SUE REU Sites, each year, the students participated in an 8-week summer engineering research project in teams of 2 to 3 students guided by two faculty mentors and a graduate student mentor. They were trained in conducting the research by these mentors and 3 enrichment seminars. Seven additional interactive skills workshops were provided to help the students produce the deliverables to disseminate their research findings. . The 3 enrichment seminars included: Ethics in Engineering Research; Taking Research from Lab to Real-World; and Graduate Education Opportunities and Application Process. The 7 skills workshops included: Safety Training; Technical Writing and Presentation; Online Literature Search; Project Documentation - Photography and Video Recording; Statistical and Uncertainty Analysis; Poster Making; and Public Speaking and Communications. In the last year (2014), an additional skills workshop on Group Problem Solving Skills was added to enhance group dynamics.

The basic approach used in the SUE REU Sites is that research is discovery through actual construction, experimental testing and/or computer simulation, observing and recording, synthesizing the data collected, and generalizations. To prepare the students for the research, reading material was sent 4 weeks prior to their arrival. In each team, one student acted as the team leader on a weekly rotating basis, and was responsible for reflecting on the daily activities in a log book. Students participated in mentored longitudinal writing assignments, oral presentations, and a juried final poster, PowerPoint, and technical paper presentation. Each Friday every mentor and REU participant completed an online Weekly Progress Report Survey Form, which had questions seeking information for number of weekly meetings held, aggregate progress made towards overall goals, and strategies implemented to enhance productivity.
